title: The Science of Habit-Forming Apps: Designing for Engagement
abstract:
Have you ever wondered why some apps keep us coming back, day after day, while others are forgotten after a single use? The secret lies in the science of habit formation ‚Äì and you have the power to use these principles to create products that not only engage but truly resonate with users.

In this talk, UX designer Tamia James unpacks the science behind habit-forming products and how you can apply it to your own app. Drawing from behavioral frameworks like the Hook Model, she'll break down how leading apps use triggers, rewards, and user emotion to keep people coming back‚Äîwithout relying on dark patterns.

Whether you're building your first iOS app or refining an existing one, you‚Äôll walk away with a toolkit for designing experiences that are not only engaging, but meaningful and ethical. Expect practical insights, real-world examples, and a fresh perspective on what it really takes to build a product users love.

title: Hello Foundation Models
abstract: Apple's foundation models offer a brand new way to make AI apps for their platforms - free & private. Let's take a deep-dive into how to use them, just how powerful they are, and how you can use them to create the next generation of apps.

title: How to Approach Approachable Concurrency
abstract:
The Swift language has gone through many significant changes recently and this year is no different. We're now seeing some of the results of efforts to improve the approachability of data race safety. Many developers have found concurrency incredibly difficult to understand, making any improvements welcome. But, how can we use these new facilities to make our transition to Swift 6 easier?

We'll go through not just what new tools we have, but why they were introduced. Whether you are just now getting started or have lots of experience with concurrency, together we can deepen our understanding of the language. You'll come away feeling confident deciding how to best approach Approachable Concurrency for your project.

title: Designing for the Post-Screen Era
abstract:
Minority Report nailed personalised advertising and biometric scanning, but watching Tom Cruise move data between computers like he's inserting a CD is painful. Cloud storage was simply unimaginable.

Every generation of designers has these blind spots. We nail some predictions whilst being completely wrong about others.

I believe our current UX patterns - app icons, login screens, settings menus - are our generation's floppy disks. We're perfecting taps and swipes whilst AI is quietly making interfaces obsolete‚Ä¶ and Liquid Glass isn‚Äôt quite the answer.

Through examples from film, historic design, and emerging research, I‚Äôll explore the assumptions baked into modern mobile design and imagine what comes after the screen entirely. Because, y‚Äôknow, the interfaces we're building today might be tomorrow's punchline.

title: The Technical Side of Liquid Glass
abstract: Liquid Glass is here! What are the new SwiftUI modifiers you actually need to know for your app to have the concentricity the Human Interface Guidelines yearns for. Let‚Äôs learn the technical side of Liquid Glass.

title: Inside Liquid Glass:¬†How iOS 26 Synthesizes Refractive UI
abstract: A reverse-engineer‚Äôs breakdown of Liquid Glass in iOS 26. Let‚Äôs explore the decades-old technologies that power Apple‚Äôs refractive materials and learn how to apply the effect responsibly along the way.

title: Live Activities - Notifications That Users Actually Enjoy
abstract:
The idea of this session is to help people discover and learn about the Live Activities APIs, which allow you to display live notifications on the Lock Screen, as well as in Dynamic Island or your Apple Watch.

The talk will be architectured as follows:

1/ Introduction
- What are Live Activities? (Apple's description, then summarized)
- A couple of examples (ride-sharing, food delivery, etc.)

2/ How do they work?
- The different SDKs involved (ActivityKit, WidgetKit, etc.)
- The life cycle of a live activity

3/ Example
- The idea is to get hands-on with the implementation of a live activity within an iOS app.
- I'll go for a straightforward but complete implementation, from adding the extension to showing it in the simulator.
- I'll of course make use of snippets and shortcuts in order to keep it as smooth as possible

4/ Unexpected live activities implementations
- Here, I aim to show that live activities are not only for ride-sharing or food delivery
- Countless apps might benefit from live activities, basically anything that's happening live and/or is time-based
- A few examples off the top of my head: Lumy can show you live activities with sunrise/sunset (with beautiful visuals), Flighty can get updates on your flight right (gate, delay, etc.), Pixel Pals simply displays a tamagotchi-like friend inside Dynamic Island, Tinder displays the amount of time remaining when you use a timer-based power up, etc.

5/ Conclusion
- Live Activities are easy to implement
- It gives your app a great amount of visibility
- You can think out of the box to add them to your app
- It's not _that_ used, it can be a differentiation factor

title: Swift on Linux on Mac
abstract: Virtualization. Containers. Deploying and Running Linux apps on Mac. State of the matter, and practical use of available tools to ship Swift on Linux on Mac

title: Building iOS Apps Without Xcode, Using Cursor, Claude Code and XcodeBuildMCP
abstract:
Do you want to improve your AI workflow? Do you want to build iOS (and other) apps without using the Xcode GUI? 
This talk is for you! You'll learn how to master Cursor, Claude Code, and how to setup your project to be built outside of Xcode. 
Building at the speed of light!

title: What Really Happens to Your iOS App During Compilation - and What It Exposes
abstract: In this session we‚Äôll dissect your .xcarchive and .ipa to show you exactly what Xcode does with your source code. We'll cover the compilation process, Mach‚ÄëO binaries, symbol tables, Info.plist, Obj-C/Swift metadata, resource catalogs, Apple signing and more. We‚Äôll demonstrate how automated tools are used to reconstruct control flow and reveal sensitive data. Then, we show how attackers can replace or patch components inside the bundle, re‚Äësign it, and distribute a repackaged version. Finally, we‚Äôll outline targeted techniques to make analysis and tampering of sensitive areas significantly harder.

title: The Wonderful World of Private APIs
abstract: We've all been tempted to use some private APIs, let's explore how it all works behind the scenes.

title: Defence Against the Analytics Regressions
abstract:
Most iOS apps track internal events using services like Firebase or Flurry Analytics. Preserving these events during code refactoring is often a delicate task. Unlike business logic or UI issues, which can be caught by unit or manual tests, regressions in analytics tracking often remain unnoticed until someone creates a report half a year later.

To address this issue for my company, I've created a simple framework that identifies regressions in analytics events using XCUITests. The principle is straightforward: after implementing event tracking for a feature, we record the events triggered during related XCUITest run and store them into a JSON file. In future XCUITest runs, we compare triggered events with their parameters to the recorded snapshot and fail the test in case of unexpected changes.

In my talk, I plan to explain the core concept of this approach and provide technical details of its implementation. I consider them interesting for the audience as they include advanced usage of protocols, mirroring, and passing data between main app and UI tests.
To better illustrate the process, I will create a simple demo app and publish it on GitHub, allowing everyone to experiment with and possibly enhance it.

title: Streamlining iOS Development with Selective Testing
abstract:
In this talk, I will delve into the concept of selective testing, showcasing XcodeSelectiveTesting. As iOS applications expand, their structure often evolves into modular designs, with clear interfaces and features separation. This growth inevitably leads to longer testing times ‚Äì a challenge that XcodeSelectiveTesting helps to address.

Selective testing focuses on assessing only the modified code and its dependencies. This strategy is particularly effective in monorepo setups.

This allows a reduction in testing times by up to 50%, significantly accelerating the CI/CD pipeline and enhancing overall development efficiency.

title: To Test Is to Doubt? Using Swift Testing as an Alternative XCTest to Improve App Quality
abstract:
At WWDC 2024, Apple turned the world of iOS Development upside down by introducing Swift Testing, a long awaited alternative to XCTest. 

How can we harness Swift Testing to write better tests? 
What powerful new features might we make use of to improve our tests, reduce the amount of bugs and grow our app's overall quality? 

This talk aims to answer those questions ... and many more. 

I'll start by giving a brief introduction about the testing pyramid, what different types of tests we can write and how most iOS developers use(d) XCTest. 

I'll swiftly move on to introduce Swift Testing, comparing and contrasting it's different features with XCTest, highlighting the improvements it brings, especially Tags, Traits, Arguments, expect, require, Test Suites, ... 

I'll conclude my talk by answering the all important question of whether or not we should migrate existing tests in our codebases to Swift Testing. Spoiler Alert: it depends. 

A tentative outline would be the following:

Introduction: 

on Software Quality and the testing Pyramid in General (2 min)

1. The Old School Approach and it's limits: using the XCTest to write tests. 

A) Writing a simple unit test in XCTest: how we used to write tests.

B) Limits to XCTest: the frameworks shortcomings why having a million different XCTAsserts didn't move the needle. 

2. Swift Testing: an open source answer to the Shortcomings of XCTest. 

A) The basics: using Suites and the new #expect Macro to organise our simple tests.   

B) More "advanced" use cases: writing parametrised tests, ... 

Conclusion: 

A) Swift Testing also has shortcomings: today you can't write performance tests. 

B) Should you migrate your existing tests to XCTest? It depends. Maybe.

title: A Talk... Two Ways
abstract: There's no one way to give a conference talk, but is there a way to do two ways in the same talk? In this talk, we'll have two speakers with different talk styles talk about the way they give a talk, so that you can figure out how to talk when you give your own talks. Watch as Zach, the over-preparer, and Josh, the extemporaneous speaker, combine forces and contrast styles to create one mega, meta talk about finding their voices and playing to their strengths to create fantastic content for captivated conference attendees.

title: When iOS Talks Back: Speaking and Listening Without Chaos
What People Get Wrong with Accessibility
abstract: It's common to hear people talk about "adding accessibility" to their apps, but in many cases the best approach is doing less, not more. In this talk, we'll explore how iOS's built-in accessibility support often works best when left untouched, and how excessive manual tweaking can actually hurt usability for real users. We‚Äôll explore how to rely on system defaults to make your app accessible with minimal extra effort, and when it's actually necessary to customize accessibility behavior. We'll also walk through real-world examples of both good defaults and harmful over-customization.

title: Crafting Reusable SwiftUI Components the Same Way Apple Does!
abstract:
What distinguishes a good UI component from a great one?
It often comes down to the developer experience ‚Äî specifically, how intuitive and flexible its public API is.

Discover powerful SwiftUI techniques to pass data and events into and out your components.
See how you can allow high customizability for your component while providing a set of features.
Learn how to build more reusable and dev-friendly SwiftUI components just like Apple does!

title: SwiftUI Apps That Effortlessly Scale from Your Smallest to Your Biggest Screen
abstract:
Write once, deploy everywhere! Exactly the same code for Apple Watch, iPhone, Vision Pro and Apple TV. Sounds too good to be true? 

Well yeah, I suppose it isn't quite that easy in practice. However, the reality is that you can share a surprising amount of view code between platforms. And with a few thoughtful considerations, you can ensure your code stays easy to read, maintain and extend.

In this session, you will learn how to structure your SwiftUI views for maximum code reuse and modularity in order to build apps for different layouts and input mechanisms. We will discuss how to abstract away any "platform-specific glue" to keep things clean at the call site and talk about best practices for backwards compatibility.

Of course, we'll also talk about Apple's new Liquid Glass design language and how that reshapes the way we should think about navigation, layout and view composition in our cross-platform SwiftUI apps.

After using SwiftUI almost exclusively over the last three years to ship apps for a large range of Apple devices, I made a lot of mistakes along the way so that you don't have to ;)

title: Better Error Handling in Swift: From Obj-C Legacy to Swift 6 Power
abstract:
Ever wondered why your carefully crafted Swift error messages never appear in console? Or how to improve system messages like "The operation couldn't be completed" with low effort? The shocking truth is: Swift's error handling is still running on Objective-C's 30-year-old architecture!

This talk exposes the hidden legacy that's been sabotaging Swift error handling and shows how to finally fix it. You'll discover why even LocalizedError isn't reliable and see what truly native Swift error handling looks like.

Swift 6's typed throws promises compile-time error safety, but it creates new challenges. I'll demonstrate the "nesting hell" problem that emerges when propagating errors across app layers‚Äîand reveal the elegant solution that preserves type safety without boilerplate.

See real transformations: complex error chains become visual debugging trees showing exactly where problems originated, and user feedback goes from "it doesn't work" to detailed diagnostic reports with one button tap and just a few lines of code.

Whether you maintain a small indie app or work on enterprise software, you'll leave with immediately applicable solutions that make debugging faster and user experience better.

Stop accepting broken error handling‚Äîit's time to bring Swift errors into the Swift era.

title: Slide Into visionOS
abstract:
Spatial Computing opens up amazing possibilities but it also introduces unique UX challenges.
In this session we‚Äôll explore how visual and audio feedback play a crucial role in creating rich mixed reality experiences on Vision Pro: we‚Äôll take an iOS custom slider as example and adapt it for visionOS.
